name: Overview
main:
Political instability has crippled Burundi’s economy and driven massive displacement, as populations continue to flee violence carried out by both the government and opposition, and their respective supporters. Deteriorating socioeconomic conditions are driving humanitarian needs for basic health and education services, as well as food, nutrition, and livelihoods support? Over 404,000 people have fled political violence to neighbouring countries since April 2015. ? By the end of 2017, it is estimated this figure will exceed 524,000. ?

Burundi, which scores 6.3/10 on the INFORM index, which is considered to be very high.?
latest_developments_past:
21/04: A WFP food shipment that was intended to feed 112,000 Burundians was blocked at the Gisenyi crossing on the Rwandan border. Burundian authorities have not commented on the cause. ?

17/04: An increase in forced disappearances, intimidation by the ruling party, and discovery of unidentified bodies observed between December 2016 and March. ? 

14/04: Government suspends opposition party, Movement for Solidarity and Democracy for six months after claiming they were planning armed resistance. ? ? 

07/04: Between 1 January and 26 March, there have been over 2.6 million cases of malaria and 1,170 deaths, compared to 1.8 million cases and 841 deaths in the same time period in 2016. ?
